data.text: INDEX
Appendix A – Outcomes for young parents and their children Appendix B – Useful contacts for supporting young parents Appendix C – Preliminary Equality Analysis
Purpose
This guideline assists health care professionals in providing a high quality service that meets the needs of pregnant young people.
By providing tailored care and support, better outcomes can be achieved and the potential for young people to achieve healthy parenthood can be maximised.
It will also make significant contributions to national and local targets on reducing infant mortality and teenage conceptions.
Equality Impact Assessment
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to Appendix C)
Background

Over the last 18 years there has been significant progress on teenage pregnancy. The under-18 conception rate has fallen by 59.7% and the under-16 conception rate by over 60%. Both are now at the lowest level since 1969 (Public Health England, 2018).

However, despite this success, a continued focus is needed. Young people in England still experience higher teenage birth rates than their peers in Western European countries , teenagers remain at highest risk of unplanned pregnancy , inequalities in rates persist between and within local authorities, and outcomes for young parents and their children are still disproportionately poor, contributing to inter-generational inequalities (Public Health England, 2018).
Pregnancy in young people is an important public health concern as it often occurs in the context of poor social support and maternal well-being. Young people and their babies
have poorer access to maternity services and experience poorer outcomes than older
people.
Pregnancy in young people is associated with significantly higher risks for both mother
and baby. (Refer to Appendix A)
Privacy and Dignity
Not all pregnancies in young people are unwanted and all staff need to be aware of the negative impact of stereotyping and adopt a non-judgemental approach to planning and delivering care.

Positive professional attitudes are essential as pregnancy in young people is often viewed negatively and young patients can feel stigmatised. This may prevent them from seeking adequate support. Staff should endeavour to be sensitive to any possible feelings of being conspicuous or embarrassed.
Planning Care
On confirmation of pregnancy the named midwife should book the patient. A full history should be taken which assesses their social, psychological, physical and emotional needs.

There should be a sensitive, confidential discussion regarding choices, ideally guided by what the young person sees as her needs. Engaging with the young person at this appointment allows the opportunity to explore the support that external agencies may offer.

Effective communication is essential when supporting young people. Verbal, non- verbal and other forms of communication should be directed towards the young patients themselves rather than other family members who may be in attendance.

If the young person is under 18 years old, she should be referred to the Specialist Midwife for Vulnerable Women using the internal referral process within Lorenzo. This provides an opportunity to discuss and plan appropriate, individualised care to provide support to young patients around the pregnancy, the decision making process and any crises that stem from their pregnancy such as ‘housing' problems.

The young person should be offered the same advice, choices and standards of care as patients in other age groups. They should be encouraged and supported to make positive choices for their pregnancy and birth to empower them as individuals.

At the booking appointment it is important to thoroughly assess support and explore all the options. It is vital to work with other services to ensure seamless provision of care that is tailored to all of their needs. Refer to useful contacts for guidance. (Refer to Appendix B)

Midwifery practitioners should ensure that they make appropriate and timely referrals to other multi-disciplinary professionals and agencies based on the teenager's individual needs ensuring effective multi-agency working.

An appointment with a consultant obstetrician should be offered to young people of 16 years of age and under. Risk status can then be decided. Following assessment of risk, young people with no clinical risk factors can receive low risk care. Patients with identified risk factors requiring consultant input can receive shared care.
When planning care, thought should be given to the ability of the young person to
attend all appointments. Financial constraints may be a problem or those studying may be unwilling or unable to take time off.
Where possible the patient should receive continuity of carer. This will allow trust to build between patient and carer and ensure the midwife can be an advocate to the patient.
Child Protection Issues

Child protection issues need to be considered and a referral made to social care if deemed necessary. In this case the midwife should discuss the case with the Safeguarding Midwife and the Specialist midwife for Vulnerable Women and Teenagers.

Consent of the young person should be obtained before any referral to social care unless there are specific child protection concerns that may endanger the woman or unborn if they knew of a referral being made.
The midwife should discuss the referral with the young person, emphasising the benefits of such a referral e.g. the capacity of social care to assess and support their needs.

While it is important to be mindful of the increased association between underage sex, self harming, domestic violence and sexual abuse not all young people fall into these categories. Some live within supportive enabling families who are capable of supporting the young person and her baby.
If Child Abuse is Disclosed or Suspected

It is important to remember the principles of confidentiality as the duty of confidentiality owed to a person under 16 in any setting is the same as that owed to any other person, but the right to confidentiality is not absolute and where there is a serious safeguarding risk to the health, safety or welfare of a young person or others, this outweighs the young persons right to privacy. (Refer to SET Procedures)
It is important to discuss your concerns with the young person, especially if you are going to break their confidentiality.

Appointments should be completed in private with no other family members/friends in order to address these issues sensitively and to maintain confidentiality. If this is not possible the midwife should aim to meet with the young person alone at the next appointment to allow her to voice any concerns not mentioned previously.
Do not initiate questions regarding sexual abuse/ domestic violence in the presence of family members/friends.

If there is a history/risk factors for mental health problems, this must be clearly documented as a risk factor on the antenatal page. An internal referral via Lorenzo should be made to the Perinatal Mental Health midwife. Consider a referral to General Practitioner (GP), community mental health team or other support service.

If child sex abuse, child sexual exploitation or domestic violence is disclosed refer to the guidelines entitled ‘Safeguarding children and young people policy 0-18 years' (register number 04064) and ‘The management of domestic abuse in maternity patients' (register number 06040). A referral to social care and the police Child Abuse Investigation Team (CAIT) may be necessary.
All referrals must be discussed with the young person. This should be recorded in the electronic communication page within Lorenzo and hospital held notes if appropriate.
Statutory Rape

Statutory rape is a term which usually refers to adults engaging in sex with minors under the age of consent. Safeguarding issues must be considered as the minimum legal age for young people to consent to have sex is  years.

Sexual activity with a child under 16 is an offence. If it is consensual, it may be less serious than if the child were under 13, but may nevertheless have serious consequences for the welfare of the child. (Refer to SET Procedures).

Sexual activity with children under 13 is always illegal as they are not legally capable of giving their consent and when a young person under 13 is found to be pregnant a referral to social care must be made.
(Refer to SET Procedures)
Between the ages of 13-15 young people of this age group must have their needs
assessed and consideration must be given for a discussion with other agencies and
whether a referral should be made to children's social care depending on the level of
risk/need assessed by those working with the young person. (Refer to SET Procedures)
Between the ages of 16-17 years sexual activity is not an offence however young people
under 18 are still offered the protection of child protection procedures. Staff must
consider issues of child sexual exploitation and offences of rape and assault. (Refer to SET Procedures)
Young people over the age of 16 and under the age of 18 are deemed not able to give consent if sexual activity is with an adult in a position of trust or a family member. (Refer to SET Procedures)
Statutory rape describes illegal sexual activity and the law assumes even if he or she
willingly engages in sexual intercourse with a legal adult, his or her sex partner may well
have manipulated or coerced the younger person.
In cases where statutory rape is identified or suspected a social care referral is required
and CAIT (Child Abuse Investigation Team) should be informed.
Subsequent Antenatal Visits

Continue to address issues and give appropriate advice and support in relation to mental and physical health at all follow up appointments. All findings, progress and any advice given should be documented in the patient's records.
Stress the importance of attending antenatal preparation classes.
Midwife should discuss benefits available and refer to appropriate agency.
Midwife should discuss their housing situation before and after birth and refer to appropriate agency as necessary.
Midwife will need to discuss education requirements and liaise with the appropriate agency.
Postpartum Management
The potential need for increased postnatal visits based on individual need should be recognised. Enhanced care should be offered to all teenage mothers.
Inform the young parent's General Practitioner (GP) and Health Visitor (ideally this should be done antenatally) especially if there are concerns around lack of support.
During the discharge visit, ensure that contraceptive advice is given and plans have been made. Encourage attendance at the six week postnatal GP appointment.
Staff and Training
All midwifery and obstetric staff are to ensure that their knowledge and skills are up-to-date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
This guideline is aimed at practicing midwives who have a responsibility to care for pregnant teenagers and to identify when appropriate referrals should be made to the lead midwife for safeguarding.
Professional Midwifery Advocates

Professional Midwifery Advocates provide a mechanism of support and guidance to women and midwives. Professional Midwifery Advocates are experienced practising midwives who have undertaken further education in order to supervise midwifery services and to advise and support midwives and women in their care choices.
Infection Prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention by ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after each procedure.
(Refer to Hand hygiene policy; register number 04072)
Audit and Monitoring

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical audit strategy and policy (register number 08076), the Corporate Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Project Plan and the Maternity annual audit work plan; to encompass national and local audit and clinical governance identifying key harm themes. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Multi-disciplinary Risk Management Group (MRMG) and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The audit report will be reported to the monthly Directorate Governance Meeting (DGM) and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Clinical Governance Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Guideline Management

As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.

Quarterly memos are sent to line managers to disseminate to their staff the most currently approved guidelines available via the intranet and clinical guideline folders, located in each designated clinical area.
Communication

A quarterly ‘maternity newsletter' is issued and available to all staff including an update on the latest ‘guidelines' information such as a list of newly approved guidelines for staff to acknowledge and familiarise themselves with and practice accordingly.
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's newsletter that is sent via email to all staff.
References
MBRRACE UK (2016) Perinatal mortality surveillance report for births in 2016 Leicester: The Infant Mortality and Morbidity Studies, Department of Health Sciences, University of Leicester.
MBRRACE (2018) Saving lives, improving mothers' care. Oxford: National Perinatal Epidemiology Unit, University of Oxford.
MBRRACE publications available at https://www.npeu.ox.ac.uk/mbrrace-uk/reports
Department of Health (2012) The family nurse partnership programme information leaflet
Available at https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/family-nurse-partnership- programme-information-leaflet

Department of Health (2010) National Service Framework for children, young people and maternity services (NSF). Standard 11; London: DOH. Available at: https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/national-service-framework-children- young-people-and-maternity-services
Public Health England, 2018. Teenage Pregnancy Prevention Framework. London: Public Health England. Available at: https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/teenage-pregnancy-prevention-framework

Public Health England, 2019. A Framework for supporting teenage mothers and young fathers. London: Public Health England. Available at: https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/teenage-mothers-and-young-fathers- support-framework
SET LSCB, 2019. Southend, Essex and Thurrock Safeguarding and Child Protection Procedures. Essex: LSCB Available at: http://www.escb.co.uk/working-with- children/policies-and-guidance/
With thanks to The Royal Free Hospital NHS Trust (2008) London
Appendix A
Outcomes for young parents and their children:
- Teenage mothers are 2 times more likely to smoke before and during pregnancy and 3 times more likely to smoke throughout pregnancy.
- Teenage mothers are a third less likely to start breastfeeding and half as likely to be breastfeeding at 6-8 weeks.
- Babies of teenage mothers have a 30% higher rate of stillbirth.
- Babies of teenage mothers have a 60% higher rate of infant mortality.
- Babies of teenage mothers are 1.9 times more likely to die from Sudden Infant Death in infancy.
- Children of teenage mothers are twice as likely to be hospitalised for gastro-enteritis or accidental injury.
- Babies of teenage mothers have a 30% higher rate of low-birth weight.
- At age 5, children of teenage mothers are 4 months behind on spatial ability, 7 months behind on non-verbal ability and  months behind on verbal ability.
- Teenage Mothers have higher rates of poor mental health for up to three years after the birth.
- Teenage mothers are 3 times more likely to experience postnatal depression.
- 2 in 3 teenage mothers experience relationship breakdown in pregnancy or the 3 years after birth.
- Children born to teenage mothers have a 63% higher risk of living in poverty.
- An estimated 12% of 16-17 year old women recorded as NEET (Not in Education, Employment or Training) were a teenage parent.
- Women who are teenage mothers are 22% more likely to be living in poverty at age 30.
- Men who were young fathers are twice as likely to be unemployed at age 30.
(Public Health England, 2019)
Public Health England, 2019. A Framework for supporting teenage mothers and young fathers. London: Public Health England.
Appendix B
Useful Contacts for Supporting Young Parents
